image.altText: A message on an eftpos machine saying there is an issue and to check connection.

items.synopsis: Train lines came to a halt, cafes couldn't take payment, triple-0 calls didn't go through. The Optus outage was more than just an inconvenience for millions of Australians.

title.children: How the Optus outage disrupted millions of Australians

image.altText: A smart phone with the message "Emergency calls only - YES OPTUS" where their signal bars should be.

items.synopsis: It's the day after the Optus outage struck more than 10 million customers and impacted health, education, transport and many other services. The ABC's consumer affairs reporter answers your questions in our live blog.

title.children: With some users still reporting no internet after Optus outage, our consumer affairs reporter answers your questions

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm going to introduce you to our national consumer affairs reporter Michael Atkin. He's on deck to answer all your questions about the situation and what Optus customers can do. If you have a question, chances are a bunch of other people will be wondering the same thing. So don't be shy! Leave a comment to ask him your questions — and I'll feed them back to you.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ask our consumer affairs reporter a question

children.content: I'm going to introduce you to our
national consumer affairs reporter Michael Atkin

props.alt: A close up of Michael Atkin

children.content: This is Michael
(ABC News)
He's on deck to answer all your questions about the situation and what Optus customers can do.
If you have a question, chances are a bunch of other people will be wondering the same thing.
So don't be shy!
Leave a comment to ask him your questions — and I'll feed them back to you.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A few of you have commented saying that your internet access was restored yesterday, but have lost your connections this morning. Here's a handful of updates from across the nation: In Brisbane and got our NBN back yesterday evening but we've lost it again this morning. Mobile services still working. — Chris Kewdale WA no internet service here. 07.00 Thurs. — Tony Optus NBN was restored yesterday around 12.30pm however went down again the morning at around 07.00 am and is yet to come back. Contacting Optus is proving to be impossible. — Timbo Service is out again in Deagon, QLD. I’d had been restored yesterday around 2pm and worked overnight. Dropped at 9am this morning and had been out since 1 — Jon Still no Optus NBN in Blackwood, Adelaide, SA. Modem restarted multiple times. I had to work from the local library yesterday, now hotspotting from my phone as I work from home. — Cathy Still no NBN service in Inner Southern suburb of Adelaide. Restarted the routers. Router is running off of backup sim card which can't handle the bandwidth. Tried to livechat with Optus support on the app but they've left me on 'read' for 10 minutes with zero reply so far. — Nic
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Scattered reports that Optus NBN is still down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The blog hasn't fully fired up this morning, so the comments queue is currently clear. But after going through the messages we received from our reader submission portal, I can see some of you are still having problems this morning. Here's a sample of some of the updates we've had from readers already today: We are Optus customers for our nbn broadband. We live in Toowoomba Qld. Our internet and landline services have not been restored as of 0549hts Thurs 9th Nov. We have not heard from Optus at all over the past 24hrs. Unable to complete online studies yesterday. We also had personal data hacked in the cyber attack. Optus have not compensated us in any way. — Kim I have not got paid — Michelle I live in Coffs Harbour and my internet services were not resumed until this morning. So Optus saying the issue was fixed by 6pm yesterday is wrong. — Barbara I am still off-line, unable to access any internet that on a daily basis I am continually sent Optus messages they are fixing NBN faults, it is abysmal service — Sue These comments have come in from people responding to our callout. The link for that page is below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some readers say they are still having problems

featuredLink.title: Have you been affected by the Optus outage? Tell us your story

children.content: The blog hasn't fully fired up this morning, so the comments queue is currently clear.
But after going through the messages we received from our reader submission portal, I can see some of you are still having problems this morning.
Here's a sample of some of the updates we've had from readers already today:

We are Optus customers for our nbn broadband. We live in Toowoomba Qld. Our internet and landline services have not been restored as of 0549hts Thurs 9th Nov. We have not heard from Optus at all over the past 24hrs. Unable to complete online studies yesterday. We also had personal data hacked in the cyber attack. Optus have not compensated us in any way. — Kim

— Michelle

— Sue

image.altText: A group of people wearing masks walking through a dirty street that is filled with white dust

items.synopsis: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says Palestinians must be able to self-govern in Gaza, as well as the West Bank, under a unified Palestinian Authority after the war, saying it's "clear that Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza". Follow live.

title.children: 'Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza': US's top diplomat outlines vision for Palestinian rule in Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari has claimed that Hamas has lost control of northern Gaza as thousands of residents have moved south. "We saw 50,000 Gazans move from the northern Gaza Strip to the south," Rear Admiral Hagari said in a televised briefing. "They are moving because they understand that Hamas has lost control in the north, and that the south is safer. "A safer area, where they receive medicine, water and food. They understand it's an improvement." Mr Hagari added that there would be no ceasefire but Israel has been allowing for humanitarian pauses at specific times to give residents an opportunity to relocate south. Meanwhile, Hamas says its fighters had inflicted heavy losses, with the armed wing on Wednesday releasing a video that appeared to show intense street battles alongside bombed-out buildings in Gaza City. Israeli tanks have met heavy resistance from fighters using underground tunnels to stage ambushes, according to sources with Hamas and the separate Islamic Jihad militant group. One clip from the Hamas video released on Wednesday showed fighters running past piles of debris and stopping to fire shoulder-propelled missiles at Israeli tanks. Another showed them shooting rifles from perches behind buildings and dumpsters. Reuters was not able to authenticate the footage. Saleh al-Arouri, an exiled Hamas commander, told Hamas-affiliated Al-Aqsa TV that Israeli forces may gain control of some areas in Gaza. "But that will not stop the resistance's fight against soldiers and tanks. The more (Israel) spreads and expands on the ground, the deeper its losses will become", he said. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel army says 'Hamas has lost control' in northern Gaza

children.content: Israel's military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari has claimed that Hamas has lost control of northern Gaza as thousands of residents have moved south.
"We saw 50,000 Gazans move from the northern Gaza Strip to the south," Rear Admiral Hagari said in a televised briefing.
"They are moving because they understand that Hamas has lost control in the north, and that the south is safer.
"A safer area, where they receive medicine, water and food. They understand it's an improvement."
Mr Hagari added that there would be no ceasefire but Israel has been allowing for humanitarian pauses at specific times to give residents an opportunity to relocate south.

Meanwhile, Hamas says its fighters had inflicted heavy losses, with the armed wing on Wednesday releasing a video that appeared to show intense street battles alongside bombed-out buildings in Gaza City.
Israeli tanks have met heavy resistance from fighters using underground tunnels to stage ambushes, according to sources with Hamas and the separate Islamic Jihad militant group.
One clip from the Hamas video released on Wednesday showed fighters running past piles of debris and stopping to fire shoulder-propelled missiles at Israeli tanks.
Another showed them shooting rifles from perches behind buildings and dumpsters. Reuters was not able to authenticate the footage.
Saleh al-Arouri, an exiled Hamas commander, told Hamas-affiliated Al-Aqsa TV that Israeli forces may gain control of some areas in Gaza.
"But that will not stop the resistance's fight against soldiers and tanks. The more (Israel) spreads and expands on the ground, the deeper its losses will become", he said.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The World Health Organization is warning there is an increased risk of disease spreading in the Gaza Strip due to Israeli air bombardments that have disrupted the health system and access to clean water and caused people to crowd in shelters. "As deaths and injuries in Gaza continue to rise due to intensified hostilities, intense overcrowding and disrupted health, water, and sanitation systems pose an added danger: the rapid spread of infectious diseases," WHO said. "Some worrying trends are already emerging." It said that the lack of fuel in the densely populated enclave had caused desalination plants to shut down, which increased the risk of bacterial infections like diarrhoea spreading. WHO said that more than 33,551 cases of diarrhoea had been reported since mid-October, the bulk of them among children under five. It said the number of children affected marked a significant increase compared to an average of 2,000 cases monthly in that age group throughout 2021 and 2022. The lack of fuel has also disrupted the collection of solid waste, which WHO said created an " environment conducive to the rapid and widespread proliferation of insects, rodents that can carry and transit diseases. " It said that it was " almost impossible" for health facilities to maintain basic infection prevention measures, increasing the risk of infection caused by trauma, surgery and childbirth. "Disrupted routine vaccination activities, as well as lack of medicines for treating communicable diseases, further increase the risk of accelerated disease spread," it warned. While there have been extremely limited deliveries of food, water and medicine to Gaza, Israel has refused to let fuel in due to concerns about its possible diversion by Hamas despite calls from the United Nations and humanitarian aid groups. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Risk of disease in Gaza soars as health system and clean water is disrupted, WHO warns

children.content: The World Health Organization is warning there is an increased risk of disease spreading in the Gaza Strip due to Israeli air bombardments that have disrupted the health system and access to clean water and caused people to crowd in shelters.

"As deaths and injuries in Gaza continue to rise due to intensified hostilities, intense overcrowding and disrupted health, water, and sanitation systems pose an added danger: the rapid spread of infectious diseases," WHO said.
"Some worrying trends are already emerging."
It said that the lack of fuel in the densely populated enclave had caused desalination plants to shut down, which
increased the risk of bacterial infections like diarrhoea spreading
WHO said that
more than 33,551 cases of diarrhoea had been reported since mid-October
, the bulk of them among children under five.
It said the number of children affected marked a significant increase compared to an average of 2,000 cases monthly in that age group throughout 2021 and 2022.
The lack of fuel has also disrupted the collection of solid waste, which WHO said created an "
environment conducive to the rapid and widespread proliferation of insects, rodents that can carry and transit diseases.
It said that it was "
almost impossible" for health facilities to maintain basic infection prevention measures
, increasing the risk of infection caused by trauma, surgery and childbirth.
"Disrupted routine vaccination activities, as well as lack of medicines for treating communicable diseases, further increase the risk of accelerated disease spread," it warned.

While there have been extremely limited deliveries of food, water and medicine to Gaza, Israel has refused to let fuel in due to concerns about its possible diversion by Hamas despite calls from the United Nations and humanitarian aid groups.
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rafah border crossing into Gaza was closed on Wednesday due to an unspecified "security circumstance" but US officials were working with Egypt and Israel to get it reopened. "Our understanding is that given a security circumstance, the Rafah border crossing remains closed today," State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel said during a regular press briefing. "This is an incredibly fluid situation. The border crossing has opened on many instances and allowed for the safe … exit for foreign nationals who have sought it," he said. Evacuations of foreign passport holders through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah, but the crossing was open again on Monday and Tuesday. The US expects the Egypt-controlled crossing will be reopened at "regular intervals" so that aid can enter the Gaza Strip and foreign nationals can continue to depart, Mr Patel said. He said 81 trucks carrying food, medicine, health supplies, bottled water and hygiene products crossed into the strip on Tuesday, bringing to about 650 the total number of trucks that have crossed since a diplomatic agreement was reached to reopen the crossing on October 21. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah crossing closed for 'security circumstance' after 81 aid trucks went through, US says

children.content: The Rafah border crossing into Gaza was closed on Wednesday due to an unspecified "security circumstance" but US officials were working with Egypt and Israel to get it reopened.
"Our understanding is that given a security circumstance, the Rafah border crossing remains closed today," State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel said during a regular press briefing.
"This is an incredibly fluid situation. The border crossing has opened on many instances and allowed for the safe … exit for foreign nationals who have sought it," he said.

Evacuations of foreign passport holders through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah, but the crossing was open again on Monday and Tuesday.

props.alt: A satelltie view of a border with car parked on one side and dirt surrouning

children.content: A satellite image shows a closer view of the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt on November 7
(Maxar Technologie via Reuters)
The US expects the Egypt-controlled crossing will be reopened at "regular intervals" so that aid can enter the Gaza Strip and foreign nationals can continue to depart, Mr Patel said.

He said 81 trucks carrying food, medicine, health supplies, bottled water and hygiene products crossed into the strip on Tuesday, bringing to about 650 the total number of trucks that have crossed since a diplomatic agreement was reached to reopen the crossing on October 21.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Singapore Telecommunications — Optus' parent company — has reported an 83 per cent rise in half-yearly profit on Thursday, helped by a gain related to regional associate Telkomsel's integration with IndiHome and higher contributions from its other divisions.. Telkomsel, the Indonesian associate of Southeast Asia's largest telecom firm, had agreed to merge with its parent's IndiHome broadband arm in an effort to expand into Indonesia's fixed broadband market. The deal was expected to completed in the third quarter of 2023. SingTel owns a 29.6% stake in the enlarged integrated mobile and fixed broadband company. "For Telkomsel, first-time contributions from IndiHome largely offset the impact of SingTel's reduced stake," the company said in a statement. It had earlier a 35% stake in Telkomsel. SingTel said its net profit for the six months ended September 30 was $S2.14 billion ($1.58 billion), compared with $S1.17 billion a year earlier. The company declared an interim dividend of 5.2 Singapore cents per share, higher than the 4.6 Singapore cents per share declared a year earlier.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus' parent company SingTel half-year profit rises 83 per cent

children.content: Singapore Telecommunications — Optus' parent company — has reported an 83 per cent rise in half-yearly profit on Thursday, helped by a gain related to regional associate Telkomsel's integration with IndiHome and higher contributions from its other divisions..

Telkomsel, the Indonesian associate of Southeast Asia's largest telecom firm, had agreed to merge with its parent's IndiHome broadband arm in an effort to expand into Indonesia's fixed broadband market.
The deal was expected to completed in the third quarter of 2023. SingTel owns a 29.6% stake in the enlarged integrated mobile and fixed broadband company.
"For Telkomsel, first-time contributions from IndiHome largely offset the impact of SingTel's reduced stake," the company said in a statement. It had earlier a 35% stake in Telkomsel.
SingTel said its net profit for the six months ended September 30 was $S2.14 billion ($1.58 billion), compared with $S1.17 billion a year earlier.
The company declared an interim dividend of 5.2 Singapore cents per share, higher than the 4.6 Singapore cents per share declared a year earlier.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has started the day higher, with industrials (+1.2%) and education (1.1%) stocks leading the gains. Eight of the 11 sectors were trading higher at open. However, the tech (-0.4%) and energy (-0.7%) sectors were down. The ASX 200 index was up 21 points to 7,015 points, by 10:15am AEDT. Biggest gains: Sayona Mining +5.8% to $0.09 Orica +3.3% to $15.56 Block +2.9% to $81.19 Polynovo +2.9% to $1.41 South32 +2.1% to $3.18 Biggest losses: Xero -5.4% to $108.70 Newmont Corp -4.7% to $53.30 Healius -2.8% to $1.92 Resmed -2.8% to $23.17 Westpac -2.5% to $21.10

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than 800 large companies paid no tax in 2021-22, an Australian Taxation Office (ATO) report reveals. The ATO's ninth corporate tax transparency report, which covers 2,713 corporate entities, found that while the amount of tax collected increased due to skyrocketing mining company profits and higher oil prices, there were still 831 (31 per cent) that did not pay a cent of tax. The report attributes no tax being paid to various reasons, including companies making an accounting loss or claiming tax offsets that reduced their tax bill to nil. Read more from business reporter Nassim Khadem. There's a searchable table in the article below for you to find out the company names.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ATO reveals the more than 800 companies that paid no tax

featuredLink.title: ATO reveals the more than 800 companies that paid no tax

The report attributes no tax being paid to various reasons, including companies making an accounting loss or claiming tax offsets that reduced their tax bill to nil.
